Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Story: I stood at the edge of the cracked driveway, my phone buzzing in my pocket with urgent messages from Mrs. Lee about her termite-ridden porch. She needed a repair plan by noon, and I knew the damage was bad enough to make the whole structure unsafe. But my attention kept flicking to my younger brother, helmet askew, eyeing the steep, splintered ramp we’d built years ago. He was determined to land a new trick, but the ramp was warped and uneven—one wrong move and he could break an arm, or worse. As his sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, keep him safe, maybe even talk him out of it. But as a carpenter, I had a responsibility to my client, to assess the damage and get her house safe before someone got hurt. My brother’s hopeful grin clashed with the anxious texts on my phone. I felt pulled in two directions, heart pounding, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
